note.body:
10-15-2019

GIMP 2.8. and Catalina 10.15

I found my solution until Apple and Gimp can work this out.

1 - I simply dragged my Gimp work folder 'MyGimpWorkFolder', located on the Desktop, to my HardDrive (Macintosh HD) under USERS - MACINTOSH HD/USERS/name_of_user/MyGimpWorkFolder

2 - LAUNCH GIMP

3 - In Gimp - OPEN FILE - Now, instead of opening the Desktop and getting the dreaded 'Could not read the contents of Desktop' (this is where my Gimp work folder was)  OPEN the name_of_user and folder name

4 - This will now work everytime when you launch Gimp instead of using the Terminal workaround

Oh yeah, not that fancy, but definitely something like this ;)

I would actually try to hack something together. I already shallowly dived into the appropriate files (at least I found them). Though I don't know when I'll find the time to really consecutively finish it, a little bit busy right now - that said it might take some time.

So if anybody else - especially if he/she has more knowledge about the gnome-shell as this is my first time ever touching the codebase - wants to also give it a try, I have no objections :P

note.body:
Hi,

I'm experiencing the exact same issue as described by OP:
~~~

I was also following this guide: https://wiki.gimp.org/wiki/Hacking:Building
and: https://wiki.gimp.org/wiki/Hacking:Building/Linux

ninja command fails on generating docs/index.html.tmp

babl-html-dump is correctly linked:
~~~
paf@msi-gs60-6qe:~/dev/gimp$ ldd repo/babl/obj-x86_64/tools/babl-html-dump 
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffe47dfb000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007fe3d8d47000)

	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007fe3d8f2b000)

	libmvec.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libmvec.so.1 (0x00007fe3d8aa8000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007fe3d8aa3000)
	liblcms2.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/liblcms2.so.2 (0x00007fe3d8a46000)
	libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007fe3d8a23000)
~~~

Suggestion from https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/babl/issues/47#note_630376 gives me, indeed, a lot of html after this short message:
~~~
paf@msi-gs60-6qe:~/dev/gimp$ BABL_PATH=/home/paf/dev/gimp/repo/babl/extensions /home/paf/dev/gimp/repo/babl/obj-x86_64/tools/babl-html-dump 
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	WARNING: the babl installation seems broken, no extensions found in queried
BABL_PATH (/home/paf/dev/gimp/repo/babl/extensions) this means no SIMD/instructions/special case fast paths and
only slow reference conversions are available, applications might still
run but software relying on babl for conversions will be slow
~~~

I'm struggling at finding what I'm doing wrong according to this thread :/
I took a look at https://wiki.gimp.org/wiki/Hacking:Building_with_Meson but couldn't find anything relevant.

events.target_title: Calendar events in popup use the wrong timezone

note.body:
I have the same bug on gnome shell 3.34.1. I imported an ics file a few weeks ago with my timetable and after an update all the events are shown now in UTC rather than my local timezone. When I create an event with a different timezone than mine, the event is shown in the dropdown in this timezone rather than my local one.

Maybe it has something to do with evolution because after the update, when I open an event to edit it in the program, the time is shown in the timezone the event was created in rather than local. There's also a field which indicates which timezone it is so it doesn't look like a bug but an intended change.

events.target_title: Fedora 30 kernel 5.3.5 mouse pointer not visible
Fedora 30 kernel 5.3.5 mouse pointer not visible

note.body:
We have since upgraded to each new kernel version and we are currently on 5.3.9-300.fc31 and at no point have we seen the mouse since the issue started.  No combination of button presses or menu selection has given even a momentary glimpse of the mouse pointer.  Changed session managers from Wayland to Xorg to X11 same result.  This issue was replicable, as we upgraded a second server and it had the same issue.  Went to install a fresh version of Fedora 31 and the UI for creating the new installation had the same issue.  Installed Mate Desktop Environment and the issue persists.

~Edit~ Whatever is causing this issue is permanent.  Reformatting our drives and using a new distro and no GNOME to fix.

events.target_title: i just report, but not understand (i dont spk english, sorry)
Any scaling leads to bad text kerning on OSX

note.body:
Same problem here. Original svg:

![0.0.1_74-PRO-brightgreen.svg](/uploads/8aa9d48ccf87cf5fc5f64c5e20fad54f/0.0.1_74-PRO-brightgreen.svg)

The code:

``` xml
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
  xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="90" height="20">
  <linearGradient id="b" x2="0" y2="100%">
    <stop offset="0" stop-color="#bbb" stop-opacity=".1"/>
    <stop offset="1" stop-opacity=".1"/>
  </linearGradient>
  <clipPath id="a">
    <rect width="90" height="20" rx="3" fill="#fff"/>
  </clipPath>
  <g clip-path="url(#a)">
    <path fill="#555" d="M0 0h57v20H0z"/>
    <path fill="#4c1" d="M57 0h33v20H57z"/>
    <path fill="url(#b)" d="M0 0h90v20H0z"/>
  </g>
  <g fill="#fff" text-anchor="middle" font-family="DejaVu Sans,Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif" font-size="110">
    <text x="295" y="150" fill="#010101" fill-opacity=".3" transform="scale(.1)" textLength="470">0.0.1 74</text>
    <text x="295" y="140" transform="scale(.1)" textLength="470">0.0.1 74</text>
    <text x="725" y="150" fill="#010101" fill-opacity=".3" transform="scale(.1)" textLength="230">PRO</text>
    <text x="725" y="140" transform="scale(.1)" textLength="230">PRO</text>
  </g>
</svg>

```

Any conversion seems to be botched, squashing the text:

* `-z 1`

![test](/uploads/63a44fc090e9846f5b20f9e59f19b0b7/test.png)

* `-z 2`

![test](/uploads/538342e6f1ae415ad904e0b721d83330/test.png)

* `-z 3`

![test](/uploads/b21f0314a494c6d6d95b9cf982d87ec0/test.png)

* `-z 20`

![test](/uploads/aece3b3a12c865cf1123dc73f2ac554b/test.png)

Pango seems to be the most likely culprit, see:

* [pango based gnuplot terminals font issues on macos](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pango/issues/422)
* [The badge is broken due to librsvg](https://github.com/HazAT/badge/issues/91)

Apparently the bug was introduced in 1.44.

events.target_title: pango based gnuplot terminals font issues on macos

note.body:
There is in fact something funny going on with > 1.43 on Mac. See:

* [Any scaling leads to bad text kerning on OSX
](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/issues/520#note_627033)
* [The badge is broken due to librsvg](https://github.com/HazAT/badge/issues/91)

events.target_title: How to keep the inode unchanged

note.body:
I have the same problem as @chaosky 

I have a **file** mounted as a **volume** inside a **docker container**.  If I modify the file on the **host**, using **gedit**, the **inode** changes and the change in not seen inside **docker container**.

I thought this behavior had been fixed 13 years ago (https://gedit-list.gnome.narkive.com/KKQE9yQB/gedit-and-hard-links) but look like someone decided to revert the change.

**Could this behavior be configured somehow?**

To @chaosky: you can use **vi** (if backup is not enabled) to change de file as inode is kept.

note.body:
Hi Igor,
Yes, you are correct, unfortunately  xfce terminals are good, but not as
flexible with multiple profiles as gnome-terminals.   Gnome-terminals have
a lot of great features, it would be really nice to get the dynamic
selection feature back in them in the future.  The gnome-terminal already
has the Edit Profile dialog,  what would it take to add a new tab to the
dialog with the select-word user control. I suppose that once the user
changes the characters, then the change would need to be dynamically
registered with the terminal on which the change occurred ???  But yes, for
the current time I have been using xfce terminals.
Thanks for your help,
-Todd

events.target_title: Provide select-by-word functionality

note.body:
Hi Egmont,
Thanks for the info, but the issue is to be able to 'dynamically' alter the
word-char-exceptions.  For example, perhaps I am editing a source file in
vim in a gnome-terminal, and I want to be able to select C++ function names
and just copy the class part.  Right now double clicking on the 'FooClass'
part of the string: 'FooClass::bar'  will capture the entire
'FooClass::bar' . In the older gnome-terminal I would change this by using
the menu: Edit->Profile Preferences, then in the dialog I would see:
                   Select-by-word characters:  -A-Za-z0-9:
and then I would remove the ':' dynamically to:
                   Select-by-word characters:  -A-Za-z0-9
and the gnome-terminal behavior was dynamically altered.
This feature was extremely useful to me in Gnome2 gnome-terminals.

The dconf solution has several issues:
(1) how would a user know the <profile-id> of the terminal that they are in?
(2) dconf does not show the 'default' characters, in Gnome2 these default
characters were shown to the user, he could then remove or replace a
character to get the desired behavior

The newer Gnome3 gnome-terminal already has the menu: Edit->Profile
Preferences and the associated dialog.  Would it not be feasible to simply
add an 'Advanced' tab to the existing dialog, and in the advanced tab you
could put the Select-by-word-characters control ?
In fact, the current 'xfce' terminals do exactly this - it would be great
if Gnome3 would provide the same easy to use functionality to it's users.

Thanks
Todd

Auto Move Windows: Strange rendering issue on Ubuntu 19.04

note.body:
Hi,

I also encounter this bug on my config (Opensuse Tumbleweed, Gnome shell 3.32 ). However i noticed that there is a shadow remaining in the current workspace only if nothing else is open in this workspace, for example :

1: On workspace 1, no application open, launch firefox (auto-move configured to open firefox on workspace 2), firefox open on workspace 2 but the shadow remain in workspace 1

2: If i have the file manager already open in workspace 1, then launch firefox, firefox open in workspace 2, but in this case NO shadow remain in workspace 1, so it works perfectly

Hope this may help to track the bug, but nonetheless thanks very much for this useful extension!

Hi guys, me again.

Did not had the time/power to re-setup my Windows build system, but had the opportunity to test the bug with both Ubuntu 19.04 and 19.10 (VM) I had at home.

What's weird is that I do not have the same behavior.

Instead of a freeze, I have an inconsistency between the fixed aspect ratio and the output resolution after selection resize.

Again, a video explains it better.
[gimp-rectangle-selection-tool-bis.mkv](/uploads/af4abdfacad7e78585cf0530f0b21950/gimp-rectangle-selection-tool-bis.mkv)

Aspect ratio forced to 1:1, initial size of 1232px x 1232px.
After resized to 2480px, size is set to 2480px x 2034px.

Again, I may be wrong, but this may be due to the round of double value send via the GTK properties (I'm sorry, I'm more of a Qt guy, not sure what the real term is) for the selection info.

I do not work this Friday, I'll try to take some time to setup my Windows.

events.target_title: Rectangle selection tool freezes UI

note.body:
Oh boy, you don't make contributions easy, don't you?
Wasn't able to build for Windows, neither from Windows nor by cross-compilation (with crossroad).

Anyway, managed to build and reproduced on an Ubuntu 18.10.
Here are some logs when the freeze happens : [trace.log](/uploads/9f3b84159e42caf92bbcecfc48bd8a79/trace.log)

You can see it starts going crazy at line 6, most probably due to the value of private->y1 after resize: -272,500000 (log printed from gimp_tool_rectangle_apply_aspect method, gimptoolrectangle.c).
This lead to another automatic resize that will change x1 value from 153,000000 to 152,500000).
After that, you can see it enters a cycle where it decrement the value of the GIMP_RECTANGLE_OPTIONS_PROP_X property by 1, until the end of times. 

Attached, 2 patches:
- One typo fix: [0001-Fix-typo.patch](/uploads/441780d33a3cf02e492f988ba24ffff0/0001-Fix-typo.patch)
- An attempt to fix the issue (seems to work, so far, but I don't have the full knowledge of what it implies): [0002-Round-final-value-when-resizing-selection.patch](/uploads/46f5d36ec08b275ca191d9be146999ad/0002-Round-final-value-when-resizing-selection.patch).

Now that I have a working setup, I'll be glad to help you in any way I can to fix this.
So feel free to ask :)

events.target_title: Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain
Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain

note.body: Reproduced with gtk4-demo (compiled with MSYS2) from the current master branch head 7a73f43de331a947da77bd51e7fd36303bb825f6.

events.target_title: Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain

note.body:
I think moving to a clipboard format listener is a good idea, but there's still an underlying issue of the GdkClipboardNotification window never receiving a WM_DESTROY message.
I have no idea why this message isn't getting sent. The equivalent Qt5ClipboardView window seems to receive it just fine when I view it in Spy++.

events.target_title: Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain

note.body:
>  Well, the hidden clipboard window is destroyed when GdkWin32Display is disposed

Are you sure about this? Is there some sort of example I can test? Since the GdkClipboardNotification window is created without any parent, it needs to be explicitly closed and I can't find any indication that gtk has code to destroy it. clipboard_window_created tells the main thread about the window handle, but I don't see anywhere this is used to destroy it.

Initially I thought this must be a regression, but I managed to reproduce this with gtk-demo.exe from [gtk+-bundle_2.24.8-20111122_win32.zip](https://download.gnome.org/binaries/win32/gtk+/2.24/gtk+-bundle_2.24.8-20111122_win32.zip), even in a Windows XP VM. Surely this must have worked at some point after https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/commit/1afc29d869f3928095864a0a05cd4a1753a488c1 or someone must have reported this earlier? Maybe I need to test a real application like GIMP from around that time to see if/how they set it up in a way that caused the clipboard viewer to be destroyed. 

I've attached a hack that works for me in the gtk-2-24 branch. [0001-hack-to-ensure-viewer-is-removed-from-clipboard-chai.patch](/uploads/ac0698be90f31967148638c526b8a72d/0001-hack-to-ensure-viewer-is-removed-from-clipboard-chai.patch). I don't know enough gtk or win32 to say if this is the best way to go, but it seems that something like this works well for gtk2, where the clipboard window is still in the main thread. 

I tried to figure out a good place to do deinitialization in the master branch, but I couldn't find one. DllMain seems like it might be a reasonable place since the window is created with the dll's instance, but for some reason the clipboard thread never seems to reach it with a DLL_THREAD_DETACH.

events.target_title: Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain

note.body:
Is there some reason not to simply use gtk_main_sync to close the displays or cleanup the clipboard? This seems like a reasonable place to cleanup since it's already used to preserve the clipboard contents when exiting an application. E.g. [0001-Add-code-to-close-displays-to-gtk_main_sync.patch](/uploads/5b0392148f4825c112cc640c6cc82adc/0001-Add-code-to-close-displays-to-gtk_main_sync.patch). If this is too invasive you could add some platform specific code.

>`gdk_win32_display_dispose()` closes the clipboard viewer window in GTK3.

Are you sure about that? I see that the display object constructs and owns some clipboard objects, but I don't see any code path causing the destruction of the clipboard window. With the patch above applied to the master branch gdk_win32_display_dispose gets called, and the GdkDisplayChange window receives a WM_DESTROY signal, but the GdkClipboardNotification window doesn't get destroyed, despite that thread and window still being alive if I pause there. 

You're absolutely right about that hack, I should've thought that through more.

>  And this doesn't help us in case a GTK program crashes (well, actually, we are kind of able to do things on crashes - that's what the vectored exception handlers are for! But it's still possible for our process to be killed abruptly). As i have said, clipboard chaining is a bad API, and that's why MS deprecated it.

I'm certainly not opposed to changing APIs. I just think it's a shame to ship cleanup code that will never get reached. Failing to call `RemoveClipboardFormatListener` is much less of an issue, but I think that at least in the simple cases gtk should call it.

events.target_title: Windows: GTK breaks the clipboard viewer chain

note.body:
>That function doesn't exist in GTK2 and GTK3. You probably mean the de-initialization in `gtk_main()`, where it calls things like `_gtk_clipboard_store_all()`. That might work, but it's more complicated than using windows, because with `gtk_main()` you have to cross the GTK/GDK barrier (i.e. GDK W32 backend gets a new function for internal use only, and GTK has to call it; In GTK4 this barrier does not exist, but GDK and GTK are still separated logically)

My bad, I was looking at GTK4 there. In essence, ``_gtk_clipboard_store_all`` in gtk3 already crosses the barrier by calling ``gdk_display_manager_list_displays`` to get a list of displays and iterate over them. Is it really that bad to do the same thing but also call gdk_display_close on each display? No platform specific code needed. gtkmain.c is where gtk creates the display manager and display in the first place, so surely this isn't such a radical change.

>There the clipboard viewer does live in a separate thread indeed, and does not remove itself from the chain. This is actually my bad, since it was me who rewrote the clipboard code for GTK4. The code calls `PostQuitMessage()` in response to `WM_DESTROY`, but to get `WM_DESTROY` someone has to call `DestroyWindow()`.

It's probably easiest to just send it a WM_CLOSE.

I like your idea about using a ref counter when a new window is created (let the object system do the work). But I do think it's legitimate for a console application to use gtk/gdk to access the clipboard. In gtk3 a GdkWindowTemp window gets created even for a console application, so you could accommodate this use case. However, in gtk4 there don't appear to be any windows created for such a minimal application other than the GdkClipboardNotification and GdkDisplayChange window (neither of which get cleaned up).

[evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch](/uploads/40e33ecef0b5a464ec8abace26a800bc/evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch)

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
patch v0.0.3 attached.  I refactored out all the nonsense with fixed-size buffer allocations and snprintf, and also refactored out all of the ad hoc case conversion nonsense.  In general, it's much more gnomish now -- I'm new to the gnome API so I've been scaling the learning curve.

As for UI/UX, the effect of the patch is exactly as you prefer.  With a single click, the user can disable notifications for a whole account, for a single folder in that account, or if that account has a multilayer folder hierarchy, for all folders under a selected parent folder.  The change is purely additive, and all existing controls continue to function as before, including "Notify new message for Inbox only".

As before, the patched code stores a list of accounts/folders for which to _disable_ notifications.  The UI tick boxes visually signify enabling (also as before), and they default to enabled, but they are rendered by logically inverting membership in the `not_folders` hash table of folder URIs.  So it's already as you (correctly) prefer.

The practical effect of the patch is that the list of accounts in Edit->Plugins->Mail Notification->Accounts becomes a list of accounts and their appropriately indented folders and subfolders, appearing at Edit->Plugins->Mail Notification->Accounts/Folders.

The code that renders the tick boxes should be enhanced so that all tick boxes hierarchically below a cleared tick box get grayed out and don't accept clicks.  I'm not a UI developer (at all...) and don't know how to do that, but I'm sure somebody else knows how!

Note, in this revision of the patch, I've updated all symbol names to use "folder" rather than "account" as appropriate, and I've also marked all references to the dconf "notify-not-accounts" node "FIXME", because the patch is neither forward nor backward compatible with the old scheme storing UIDs there.  You will need to decide what you want to do about that, e.g. transparently importing old `notify-not-accounts` UIDs as initial URI members of a new `notify-not-folders`.  The dconf taxonomy will need to be correspondingly adjusted.

[evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch](/uploads/4366ec5496ec703180a502d5461e9a8e/evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch)

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
OK I've evolved things in the direction you describe, and I think it's much closer now (though definitely still work to do).

Headlines:

* The dconf schema is now patched to add "notify-allow-folders" and "notify-suppress-folders" nodes, and the old "notify-not-accounts" node is currently never accessed by the patched code, but is left in the schema unchanged.  Thus it is now possible to try out the patched plugin, or manually migrate to it, then revert.

* The evaluation machinery (hash table) now tracks `NOTIFY_EXCEPTION_SUPPRESS` and `NOTIFY_EXCEPTION_ALLOW` expressly.  The tree search in `can_notify_folder()`, which starts from the bottom and works its way up to the whole account, now terminates decisively for the first LHS that has a value, which can be either `_SUPPRESS` or `_ALLOW`.

* Thus we now have generalized machinery that allows for efficient and intuitively clear representation and evaluation of any possible user preference.  In particular, it now handles the case of a no-notify account with a yes-notify folder under it, or a no-notify upper folder with a yes-notify subfolder.

I haven't yet worked on the actual UI tick box dynamics.  The machinery for _evaluation_ of the new "notify-allow-folders"/`NOTIFY_EXCEPTION_ALLOW` is fully implemented, but there isn't yet any logic to _populate_ "notify-allow-folders", pending figuring out the UI.

My gray-out idea definitely won't work: if a folder is grayed when its parent is no-notified, it would be impossible to add an exception to allow the folder.

I _believe_ it would work best to just have the children of a node follow their parent, except that nodes that have an exception set (either to allow or suppress) would keep that manually set value.  The tick box states would be computed by calling `can_notify_folder()`, which keeps the code orthogonal and gives by-definition consistency between the tick boxes and the actual behavior.  I haven't written this code yet but it's next (at which point the patch will be fully functional).

The only trouble I see here is that there needs to be an easy way for the user to revert a folder to its inherited default, i.e. to clear a manually set value.  Ideas?


Re your unaddressed/unresolved points:

>you still use `strlen ("folder://")`

This is a good practice I learned from a coworker some time ago.  `strlen()` really is the function desired, and modern compilers (certainly `gcc`, probably the rest too) optimize it away to an int constant.  The advantage of using `strlen()` is more obvious when the argument isn't a string literal -- by comparison, I've gotten into trouble on occasion using `sizeof(x) - 1` when I thought `x` was an array but it was actually a pointer.

>Could you generate the diff with git, eventually with diff -up, please?

Sure, doing `diff -up` now.  Was `diff -u` before.

>Why do you construct the folder URI on your own? Is there a reason to duplicate the code, not to use e_mail_folder_uri_build() and e_mail_folder_uri_equal()?

Unfortunately, we can't use `e_mail_folder_uri_equal()` because `g_hash_table_*()` requires a comparison function with arg structure like `g_str_equal()` (two `gchar *` args).

As for `e_mail_folder_uri_build()`, it doesn't know how to construct URIs for subfolders.  However, I was able to get rid of `g_uri_escape_string()` and the associated escape character case mismatch, by following the code in `e_mail_folder_uri_build()`, which uses `camel_url_encode()`.  So the matching logic is much less ridiculous now.

>I prefer to have the folders and accounts in separate keys (I thought I mentioned it somewhere, but I do not see it now). It'll avoid issues with backward/forward compatibility.

That's not exactly the way it's done in the latest version of the patch, but I'm trying to do things in the simplest most intuitive and readable way, since I don't have a lot of time to put into it, and I don't want to get confused (or have a lot of explaining to do:-).  I believe we actually only need a single auxiliary function, that populates "notify-suppress-folders" from "notify-not-accounts" at startup if the latter exists and has members, but the former does not or is empty.  I think it's a bad idea to have "notify-not-accounts" continue to be updated from top-level-account URIs in "notify-suppress-folders", because that can have surprising results if a user is relying on exceptions in "notify-allow-folders" to see notifications.  And the same rationale argues against refactoring the patch so that account-granularity suppression is stored in "notify-not-accounts".  Things just work qualitatively differently once notification control has folder granularity.

[evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch](/uploads/b5b67cc0234d042542b9ba7e31c708f8/evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch)

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
I thought some more about the question of "an easy way for the user to revert a folder to its inherited default, i.e. to clear a manually set value".

I was overthinking it and it's actually very easy -- if an exception has been set for a child URI, that means (by definition) that its tick box has the opposite value from its parent's tick box.  So if the user toggles the child's tick box to match the parent, or the parent's tick box to match the child, that should simply clear the exception (removing the URI from the hash table and dconf list, and restoring it to implicitly inherited status).

As the patch is now, the user sees all the accounts and folders, in the same exact layout as the main mail reader display.  Completely obvious, and avoids the "All Folders" / "Selected Folders" radio button complexity.  With the above plan for managing exceptions and inheritance, the results of pecking at the tick boxes will be self-explanatory and unsurprising, and the hash table and dconf lists will always be as small as possible.

I can code up this final bit (and "notify-not-accounts" importing) over the weekend.  I think we're almost there.

Thanks again for all the help gnomifying my code!

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
I've completed the GUI dynamics for this, and have been burning in the code for a couple days now.  I like where it's landed.  A couple minor adjustments gave the results I was hoping for.  The most important aspect is that each check box now always reflects the current notification status of its account/folder, with proper inheritance.

A final touch is that spam/trash folders are now suppressed by default, and require direct (non-inherited) selection to enable notification.  Other than that, it's simple inheritance with inherited exceptions, with a top level default allow.

Some examples: if an account is suppressed, all the folders under it are suppressed (and their checkboxes are cleared to reflect it).  If a folder under a suppressed account is then enabled with an exception, its subfolders (if any) are also thereby enabled.  And then one of _those_ subfolders could be disabled with another exception.  E.g. a gmail account could be disabled, but its `[Gmail]` folder could be enabled, but then `[Gmail]/All Mail` could be suppressed.

A final fine point is that if the parent of an exception folder is toggled so that the exception is no longer needed, the exception nonetheless remains as part of the persistent state (in the dconf).  This is so that if the parent account is toggled again, the exception for that folder comes back into force.  Otherwise the user would be surprised to see that toggling an account or folder back and forth immediately wipes out all of the exceptions they'd created under it, which would be very annoying.  A user-registered exception is completely cleared only when the user directly toggles the checkbox for that folder to set it equal to its default/inherited value.

By the way, you were right about `e_mail_folder_uri_build()` -- it does deal with subfolders correctly.  Part of my confusion was due to `g_uri_escape_string()` escaping `/` but `camel_url_encode()` not.

Note that I haven't yet dealt with the backward-compatibility dconf issue.  The architecture I've gone with won't allow continuation of the old notify-not-accounts node, but as I explained earlier, in my view that's an inevitable feature, not a bug, of a transition to folder-granularity notification control.

[evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch](/uploads/4f6b7dda4c77476ec416ad477dea4bf6/evolution-mail-notify-by-folder.patch)

note.body:
>I cannot accept this change with something what pretends to use levels for folders [...] There are widgets which can help you with this

Ah ha!  I didn't understand what you were saying about this earlier, despite several reads.  I completely agree -- I'll have to refactor this (will start work on it next weekend).  Thanks for clarifying.

>what is your folder structure, please? Is it flat or deep?

Both.  5 IMAP accounts with varying structure.  The inheritance behavior is really obvious -- have you tried it yet?

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
Ah yes, I did misunderstand the inbox-enabled aspect.

By the way, in the early going with the patch, there was no inheritance logic, and I found it to be highly counterintuitive, to the point of seeming just plain wrong.  I let it ride for a couple weeks (used it that way), and it never started seeming right to me.  So I took the time to figure out and implement inheritance, and it worked as I had hoped.  Inheritance has definite elegance to it.

The use case you're describing does inherently entail 27 exceptions.  But it may be somewhat contrived, given that all folders with type `_TRASH` or `_JUNK` default to suppressed regardless of the parent (no inheritance).

Regardless, I recognized that there will be the rare user that makes particularly intense use of folder hierarchies, and may indeed configure careful, valuable, extensive exception sets, which is why I went to extra trouble to arrange so that exceptions aren't lost even if the user accidentally toggles a parent.  I.e., once an exception is set for a folder, that folder is excluded from inheritance until the exception is directly cleared by the user.  (And the excepted folder's children inherit the exception, subject of course to additional exceptions for the children.)

Regarding your particular use case: one way that would come into play is if someone is using sieve to sort incoming mail into myriad subfolders of inbox, with the mail landing directly in the inbox when sieve doesn't find a matching subfolder.  Here, the user might indeed want notifications for the parent inbox and for a sparse subset of the subfolders.  I think it is OK that the user has to click off each of the folders he wants to be no-notified, after he's gone to the (much greater) trouble of configuring the sieve scripts for the folders in the first place.  And I think this is probably a rare use case.

Anyway, perhaps it's time for you to test drive the patch and see what you think!  (Bearing in mind that it doesn't yet have correctly widgeted tree view layout in the config menu.)

events.target_title: mail-notification: Allow to enable per-folder notifications

note.body:
More detailed thoughts on this coming this weekend...  But quick thoughts now:

>When the notify for Inbox only is off [...] The default should be no folders, or only Inbox.

Unless I misunderstand -- I'm sure that's not the right idea, as it's radically different from the current behavior, and, at least to me, very surprising (and in fact quite annoying), regardless of current behavior.  When I remove a limit, the immediate result I expect is more inclusive behavior.  You're describing a behavior where removing a limit (notify for inbox _only_) causes either no change in behavior, or an actual _tightening_ of the limit (to zero folders globally), as the immediate consequence of the gesture.  Users would find that baffling and infuriating!

>disabled accounts will not have shown anything under them.

You mean, launch in the UI tree-collapsed?  Definitely seems like the right idea.  I haven't started looking at the multilevel tree widget model stuff yet, but it sounds like a no-brainer to have any part of the tree that has nothing enabled under it, be collapsed at the start.


Bigger picture: implicit inheritance has pluses and minuses, from a UX perspective, but it's clean.  I hope I can convince you that it's at least as good as alternatives that involve extra buttons, since the implementation and explanation of nearly-pure, implicit inheritance, is so conceptually clean.  This speaks to your concerns about sustainability, and that's no accident on my part.

The implicit-inheritance-plus-exceptions approach is the simplest possible system that gives the user total control of individual account/folder status, while also giving the user a way to change the status of many folders, in comprehensible and often useful groupings, with one gesture.  Of course it's possible to come up with use cases for which implicit-inheritance-based accelerations aren't a good match, but more complicated alternatives have their own problems, and complexity is a high cost to pay.

events.target_title: Gkr-pam:  unable to locate daemon control file

note.body:
Just to add another data point, I've been randomly getting this error with Ubuntu 9.04 (3.32) and Ubuntu 9.10 (3.34).

Every time this error happens, precisely 10 seconds later I get another one from Gnome Shell, and my system freezes completely, requiring a reboot. This has been happening at random times on a daily basis.

```
Oct 20 10:43:11 transltr gdm-password][2199]: gkr-pam: unable to locate daemon control file
Oct 20 10:43:21 transltr gnome-session-binary[1617]: Unrecoverable failure in required component org.gnome.Shell.desktop
```

I have no extensions enabled on Gnome Shell, and in fact I use the default settings from a fresh install (with the exception that I use i3wm).

events.target_title: Make it possible to shut down the computer the instant the power button is pressed

note.body:
First: really sorry to commend in a (closed) 6 months old issue.

The reason about this feature (press power off to shutdown): a lot of people use Ubuntu to provide Linux box solutions for their customers.

In the past, I've used some other lean desktop environments, but now Gnome is improving a lot (in a lot of senses: better and better UX, low memory usage), I started to use Gnome in some kiosks, headless or emulation boxes (with retropie).

A lot of times, customer have no even idea that the box is a complete PC with Linux. A lot of times it's a headless/mouseless/touchpadless environment. They expect it to work like any other electronic home device: press the power off button is the only option to power off the system. 

But usually when they press the power off button and they see the system is not powering off (because it has to wait 1 minute), they'll just pull the plug.

So, why not just a dconf key to enable advanced users to reduce it (or set to `0`) the power off waiting time?

events.target_title: Make it possible to shut down the computer the instant the power button is pressed

note.body: Another idea: add a different `chassis_type` (like `embedded`), that will work similar to `vm`, when power off is pressed.

push_data.commit_title: Always power off embedded systems when power off is pressed in the ...

events.target_title: Always power off embedded systems when power off is pressed in the menus
Always power off embedded systems when power off is pressed in the menus

note.body:
Thank you @bberg for taking a look on it.

I'm using a Gnome small form factor PC for the several scenarios (a gamebox PC, like a console; kiosks, self checkout terminals), but basically using a dedicated frontend that starts automatically over Gnome. 

I could use Xorg/Wayland directly, but Gnome offer a much better UI to manage system (connect to networks, etc). And it's getting better and better in resources usage, so it's a good fit for these cases.

In most cases, like in a "consolised" gamebox (a PC running a frontend for several games and retro emulators), customer don't have a mouse/keyboard, and the frontend blocks customer to access the system (really like any embedded system), the only way to turn off the system is pressing the power button.

What always happen when customer press the power button and don't see the system powering off (because it's waiting 30 seconds): they'll press down the power button until power down immediately.

events.target_title: Always power off embedded systems when power off is pressed in the menus

note.body: Well, I don't see why in an embedded system user needs to see the power off count down dialog from Gnome instead of immediately shut down.

That makes a lot of sense actually, however the RSS specification [specifies](https://validator.w3.org/feed/docs/rss2.html#ltimagegtSubelementOfLtchannelgt) that a channel can also have an image which is also the case for this feed:


```xml
<image>
  <link>https://tweakers.net/</link>
  <title>Tweakers</title>
  <url>https://tweakimg.net/g/if/logo.gif</url>
  <height />
  <width />
  <description>Tweakers</description>
</image>
```

events.target_title: Incompatibility with Wayland and openvt

note.body:
By comparing the logs from X11 and Wayland, I figured out that `openvt` doesn't seem to get the correct number of virtual terminals. If I call 
```
# logger STARTING OPENVT && openvt -ws -c 5 sleep 5
```
it works also with Wayland. But of course only when tty5 is not already in use.
Can anyone help me figure out why the calculation of used ttys doens't work with wayland?

# loginctl --no-legend 
SESSION UID USER       SEAT  TTY 
     c1 118 Debian-gdm seat0 tty1
```

GDM with wayland after login
```
# loginctl --no-legend
SESSION  UID USER SEAT  TTY 
      4 1000 t    seat0 tty2
```

The difference is, with Wayland GDM doesn't officially use tty1 anymore after a login. But it is actually automatically restarted whenever switching to tty1.
In contrast, with X11 GDM always claims tty1.

```
# loginctl --no-legend  # X11
SESSION  UID USER       SEAT  TTY 
      4 1000 t          seat0 tty2
     c1  118 Debian-gdm seat0 tty1
```

This inconsistency, which results in erroneous behavior with openvt and the like, still feels like a bug to me.

events.target_title: Incompatibility with Wayland and openvt

note.body: From my understanding, this inconsistency has been added on purpose with 904b254f819f5a1efb2c9ac96ba4712ed9dc6ef3 because of #222. Maybe there is a better solution to mark tty1 as occupied?

events.target_title: Metered data UI

note.body:
My recollections of some of these decisions might not be 100% accurate. Its been well over a year since I've worked on this project, but I'll try to explain some of the rationales to the best of my memory

> My initial take on this is that it should generally just work silently. If auto-updates is enabled and you're on a metered connection, it just shouldn't update. There could maybe be an indication of the current state next to the setting, but I don't particularly see the need to have a prominent indication that auto-updates have been paused.
> 
In an ideal situation, this should just work silently, that was something we discussed early on in the design process of the feature. Unfortunately working silently falls short for a couple of reasons. 

From what I understand there is no way for us to accurately detect wether a user is on an unlimited or metered connection. If we were able to detect the machine's connection type then it would make sense for us to switch automatic updates on/ off according to the type of connection they have. Without the ability to accurately detect their connection type there isn't a way to automate this and make it work silently in the background.

Given the fact that we aren't able to detect the machine's connection type, we need to err on the side of caution since many of our users are on a metered connection. The risk here is having automatic updates on then installing big updates and pushing them over their bandwidth cap, causing them to incur heavy fees/ bills. This would be a terrible situation because goes against one of our core user promises.

Since we aren't able to reasonably infer the computer's connection state, we chose instead to keep them informed and empower them to change their settings as needed. It isn't ideal but it is better than inadvertently spending their bandwidth when one of our primary product goals is to respect users' data.



 > I don't think that a dedicated settings panel is what we want here, either, I'm afraid. It's too much for what I think is a detail for most of our users (albeit a detail that needs to work well), and I don't recall seeing an equivalent UI on other platforms. 

I agree that the settings panel feels a bit heavy. Maybe there's a lighter touch solution that can be done. Maybe we can dig into this settings panel a little more and see if there is another solution here.

One thing that comes up for me that I recall struggling with when we were initially designing this feature is that there are two states that are covered in the settings panel that are seemingly related but have very different functions and could be very confusing to the users. That is the connections state (the top box in the settings panel) and the automatic updates toggle. In my mind, the only one of those that is of consequence to the users is the automatic updates toggle. That is the setting that actually controls what happens with automatic updates. What is the main reason for the user to set their connection status?

I recall going back and forth with @feaneron for a while to make the right distinction between automatic updates on/off VS limited/ unlimited connection. I think even the language describing the type of connection can vary by locale and can add to the confusion. Some places call it metered, others call it limited. Do we need to burden the user with this setting? Maybe it's simpler to just allow them to turn automatic updates on/ off since that is the core use purpose of this feature.

events.target_title: Metered data UI

note.body:
I like the sound of "Do you want automatic updates while on this network." It is concise but specific. I think having the word "automatic" is important because it communicates that it will happen automatically in the background. I wonder if downloads can be implied, but maybe it is important to include as well to be specific that downloads will occur. I want it to be specific without becoming word soup.

Alternately, "Do you want automatic downloads and updates while on this network." I feel like that covers all the bases without becoming too confusing.

events.target_title: Metered data UI

note.body:
It might be helpful to understand the context of this dialog. Does it appear in a normal setup? flow for a new connection or do you have to optionally drill down into details to see this. If it is part of the normal setup flow then I might suggest that this feels a little heavy. If it is information that you optionally drill in to then it might not be discoverable enough to help many of the primary target users for this feature. 
![image953](/uploads/ba268dffab1192589aef94ab08c1df49/image953.png)

This is a minor thing, but I wonder if this UI could have an accordion expand to reveal more info rather than revealing the additional info in a new window. It might feel like a lighter weight interaction and a better use of space.![Screen_Shot_2019-12-19_at_2.24.44_PM](/uploads/df49198b52984e35c6e0458c4cfbdd63/Screen_Shot_2019-12-19_at_2.24.44_PM.png) 

This UI element uses the accordion expand pattern I mentioned above. I think it is a great,  lightweight way of having a progressive reveal of small amounts of information. It works great here. My only comment here is an aesthetic one. The color is really funny. It has a strange salmon tone. Is there a pattern or system for this color palette choice? I wonder if something more nuetral or cool toned would be better. I understand that it should be set apart from the general gray tones of the window.
![Screen_Shot_2019-12-19_at_3.27.47_PM](/uploads/f133d582edd9a26a3b6f26ee88d7bc91/Screen_Shot_2019-12-19_at_3.27.47_PM.png)

Where is the update prefences modal accessed from?

events.target_title: Metered data UI

note.body:
>  Having the whole infobar clickable would be possible, but afaik there’s nothing currently in the widget which provides feedback to the user about it being clickable (like different background colours on hover, or anything like that). 

Having the entire info bar clickable makes some sense from a usability standpoint. But I agree, for this to work there needs to be visual feedback to the user to indicate that they can click there. Would that be difficult to build into the widget's styling options? It would be a nice UX feature to make available that will most likely have other useful applications.

>  It might be a bit undiscoverable to the user compared to a specific button.

There is precedence for still having the the button there as the primary indicator. Some users will still go navigate to click the button specifically. Some users will see that that bar is clickable and just click that.

events.target_title: X11: Drop-down menus from menu bar don't react to touchscreen taps

note.body:
Ok, may be I was a bit too frustrated about the situation. But let me add here:

1. It looks like to bug exists for a long time.
2. I (and many others) could see it on different machines with different windows managers
3. If you use classic menu button based menus, ALL touchscreen seems to be unusable.
4. Even the new code gives benefit, breaking old stuff is no benefit. If you have a touchscreen, it worked before, after you cant anymore work with it.

If I would be a c programmer, I myself would go deeper in the code. Unfortunately this is not the case. But I'm ready to help whatever help I can give the project. So my proposal is:

a) I can send to the project the needed hardware to see
b) I'm ready for all assistant I can do
c) I already sent a solution so it does not breaking working with touch screens. It looks like this is only a solution for solusOS and/or mate based windows managers, but I think this information is usefully for everybody that has the same problem.

So I invite everybody to find a solution for this problem because I think it is a rarther ugly big one. And yes, tell me what I can do or how I can help to go for a solution.

Voila!

events.target_title: Default bounding box should encompass entire drawing

note.body:
Svgcleaner appears to be primarily for shrinking svg files. It does not work out of the box as it does not add a viewBox:

```
$ target/release/svgcleaner circle.svg foo.svg
Your image is 50.00% smaller now.
$ cat foo.svg
<svg><ellipse cx="300" cy="300" rx="50" ry="50"/></svg>
```

I also tried `scour`, which is similar to `svgcleaner` and it did the same thing. It didn't even add a viewbox when I specified `--enable-viewboxing`:

```
$ scour --enable-viewboxing circle.svg 
Scour processed file "circle.svg" in 3 ms: 145/110 bytes new/orig -> 131.8%
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
 <g>
  <ellipse cx="300" cy="300" rx="50" ry="50"/>
 </g>
</svg>
```

events.target_title: Gnome Shell Issue with some extensions.
vte.sh: improvement - simple hook function to preserve user custom prompts

note.body:
Sorry if I'm bumping an old discussion, but let me see if I understand the summary correctly.
1.  Combining vte.sh with for example liquidprompt leaves the user with either a completely working vte prompt or completely working liquidprompt depending on the order they are sourced. The second one works 100% and the changes of the first one are completely overridden.
2.  Without vte the only functionality lost is opening a new tab in the current directory.
3.  Fixing this in vte is possible but ugly and leaves place for bugs.
4.  Fixing this in liquidprompt is impossible. Or is it just ugly in the same way, while being an even more wrong place to address the problem than vte?
5.  Fixing this in the distro is possible, but will still be ugly. It requires more user demand, but would show that there is a problem requiring a more clean solution.
6.  Fixing this in bash would require some design decisions, which requires terminal developer demand, which would require either:
    *  big user demand on the terminal developers
    *  many terminal devs to **really** want a clean interface for the betterment of mankind and/or personal satisfaction

My personal question is: what are the options for me as an end user? Can I do something without patching vte.sh myself? If I lose nothing but same-directory new tab, and need to do something more invasive than a profile.d script, it's not worth it. If this is the case, I see why there is not a lot of demand for a fix. A minority wants custom prompts, a fraction of them cares about same-dir.

events.target_title: Add tls-version-min and tls-version-max support

note.body:
Can we increase the priority of the reviewing of this, please?  In Debian Buster, OpenSSL is configured to *disable* TLS 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2 by default.  As a result, systems using TLS 1.0-1.2 cannot be connected to UNLESS you can pass the min/max versions of TLS to allow, so that OpenVPN can handle the TLS negotiation independent of the default OpenSSL settings.

I have taken the latest version of this diff, from 2 months ago, and tested in Debian against version 1.8.10 of the plugin that's packaged there, and this appears to work.  However, this needs to be merged here before it can be truly considered downstream for inclusions.

I'd be a STRONG supporter of this being included in the Network Manager integration because it is critical for those using Debian Buster to continue to use OoenVPN servers that don't have TLS 1.3 available thanks to Debian's decision to drop TLS <1.2 protocol support by default in its generic OpenSSL configs.

events.target_title: Feat: Beets Integration

note.body:
It does write the information as tags to the files. However there is information that it would be nice to provide to beets (such as `play_count`, `skip_count`, `last_played` and `rating`) which lollypop currently keeps to itself (or doesn't collect, in some cases).

This is unfortunate as I like to listen through lollypop, and want to generate semi-random playlists based on a **weighted** parameters such as `play_count` and `rating` using beets' API.

Currently this is impossible.

events.target_title: Feat: Beets Integration

note.body:
I am afraid my reply may have been ambiguous because I think you misunderstand.

I am advocating for the integration of beets because it provides a method of storing information on my music library far beyond anything else I have seen. As such I believe it would be worth lollypop being able to provide some information which it currently keeps to itself.

As for the example (which is just one of many) is not something that can be done with smart playlists.

```
but can't see how I could get `Rating`, or be updated when it changes.

Do you know if these two things are posible?

events.target_title: Visual Niggle: Styling of playback time
Visual Niggle: Styling of playback time

note.body:
Numbers with constant width are often called "tabular figures" (as oposed to "lining" or "proportional" figures)
![image](/uploads/7a7627dbce070df67a881f9fc30ccad6/image.png)

As far as I know, most common fonts just have tabular figures anyway, this is so that numbers line up nicely in tables. For example it seems my DE uses Noto Sans by default, and you can see that in all the font families the numbers are fixed-width.

![image](/uploads/04ce67f1f891893a3c8446c42bff750c/image.png)

In addition, for open-type fonts with multiple variants, you can use the `font-variant-numeric: tabular-nums;` css selector.

Out of curiosity, was there an issue raised with the previous font choice that prompted this?

events.target_title: Need Office 365 support in Online Accounts

note.body:
Another use case is for OneDrive.  I have a terabyte of space that it would be nice to be able to access using Nautilus.  The existing Online Account entry for Microsoft (which I guess is just for mail and documents) doesn't work for Office365 users.  There are apparently two types of authentication tools that can be used by third-party applications, at least from what I've surmised from similar issues with using connecting my OneDrive account to file manager apps on my Android phone.  My O365 email works on some of those apps and on others, I get the following error:

`That Microsoft account doesn't exist. Enter a different account or get a new one.`

When logging in on the OneDrive site directly, it looks like Microsoft's authentication is based on what the initial email validation shows for the address.  For a "regular" Microsoft account, it directs to:

`https://login.live.com/login.srf?wa=wsignin1.0&rpsnv=13&ct=**********&rver=7.1.6819.0&wp=MBI_SSL_SHARED&wreply=https:%2F%2Fonedrive.live.com%3Fgologin%3D1%26mkt%3Den-US&lc=1033&id=************=sky&mkt=en-US&lw=1&fl=easi2&username=XXXXX@domain.com`

And for an O365 email account, it redirects to:
`https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/authorize?client_id=********-****-****-ce00-000000000000&response_mode=form_post&response_type=code+id_token&scope=openid+profile&state=OpenIdConnect.AuthenticationProperties%3dT_SUPERLONGTOKENSTRING&nonce=ANOTHERSUPERLONGSTRING&redirect_uri=https%3a%2f%2fportal.office.com%2flanding&ui_locales=en-US&mkt=en-US&client-request-id=ANDYETANOTHERSUPERLONGTOKEN&login_hint=USER%40DOMAIN`

events.target_title: add tap-and-drag option

note.body:
My opinion is admittedly biased, but I think that it's important to allow tap-and-drag to be disabled or to make disabling it be the default.  I filed the original request asking for a way to turn it off because I couldn't use gmail.  In gmail, if I want to check the checkbox next to multiple messages in a row, I click each one in series.  This means that I drag my finger to position the cursor over the first box, then I lift my finger and tap to check it, then I put my finger back down to move to the next checkbox, then I lift my finger and tap, etc.

With tap-and-drag on, this results in dragging the messages around instead of checking the boxes.  The only workaround is to go very very slowly.

One way to clarify the option would be to have a two-line description along the lines of "Natural Scrolling".  The top line would say "Tap and Drag", and the bottom line would say something like "Tap then move finger on touchpad to drag".

My personal preference would be for this to default to off and to allow enabling it as a tweak or as an option in the control center.

events.target_title: Accessibility zoom position resets every few seconds

note.body:
If you don't need focus-/caret tracking I suggest you disable those, that should remove the "stuttering".

The focus-/caret tracking options are not available in the gnome-settings, disable them using `gsettings` tool from the terminal.

```
$ gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.a11y.magnifier caret-tracking none
$ gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.a11y.magnifier focus-tracking none
```

This will make the magnification experience more enjoyable.

events.target_title: automatically obtain PGP keys for e-mail recipients via keyserver
automatically obtain PGP keys for e-mail recipients via keyserver

note.body:
I understand that the before mentioned "additional features" require significantly more effort. It would have been better to request them in a separate issue.

I would fully agree with your argument to let GnuPG solve the issue, as soon as the change request [1] on GnuPG is actually confirmed to be implemented in future. At the moment it is still uncertain whether this is something the GnuPG maintainers want or if the current behavior of GnuPG is intended.

I suggest to leave this issue open and to wait a reasonable time for the GnuPG maintainers to make a decision, check if the change request has been accepted and if necessary reconsider to implement at least a basic fix.

[1]: https://dev.gnupg.org/T4726

events.target_title: Disable edge-resistance for now, re-enableable via dconf toggle

note.body:
I just want to add my support to the people making this request proposed by @chrisjbillington. I wasn't aware of this place, but after searching often to locate what this problem actually is (I think it's why I stopped using the old/classic gnome many years before actually) I had to leave some comment about this. I always thought this was a bug and am shocked to discover it's a FEATURE!

The only time I use gnome is when configuring it for someone else who is not used to computers and wouldn't want to use a more complicated setup such as tiling window manager etc. That said, I really appreciate/love the design of the shell and workspaces. But in regards to this aspect it's like you're using a low end graphics card when the windows all get stuck to each other.

It seems to me that most non technical people are going to have difficulty requesting a feature (or even a bug report) in respect of this issue because when you search for what it is, there is much confusion between A. Snapping to screen edge, or B. To other windows; and further, the former edge tiling/snapping seems to be prolifically mentioned or referenced wherever you happen to look.

I am not very experienced though so I am afraid to compile my own gnome with these changes if that is what is required since it might screw things up here if I get an update in the future on this PC. I do a bit of (very light) coding for fun so I am to an extent aware of the extraordinary effort required to maintain software especially free software as mentioned above. But I hope this proposed feature is accepted. Thanks very much to all! <3

events.target_title: seahorse 3.20.0 consumes all RAM and CPU

note.body:
Can reproduce on Arch Linux with `seahorse 1:3.34-1`, `gnupg 2.2.17-2`, trust model `tofu` or `tofu+pgp`.

It would appear this is in fact due to a [deadlock in GnuPG](https://dev.gnupg.org/T3748) that happens when you ask for `--list-keys` and `--list-private-keys` at the same time. The suggested workaround is to perform both requests sequentially.

Plugins

note.body:
Hi,

TLTR: Is there anything we can test or help with?

just as some few additional thoughts, reading through this issue... 

Putting as much of the functionality in different plugins has the already mentioned advantage of being easier to debug. It is (and might be really) just a form of making sure everything belongs to a certain class and interacts to other parts with a defined interface.
Even if users, do not switch those plugins on or off, for the further development, it can prove to be superior, as people can develop independent of the up-stream code new or alternatives parts. Esp. the alternatives could prove to be nice. E.g. one could develop a QT or a Web interface in parallel, without messing with the GTK interface and easily switch between all of them for debugging and testing. Or someone likes another OCR program, and wants to integrate it. It would simply be just another plugin. Within the plugin management, there could be something like an experimental, testing, stable section to get early user feedback, yet do not jeopardize those users, who rely on stability. 

This enables upstream to be kept mature and stable and independent of different plug-in developments. Every plugin can take its own development pace. For this reason I would also consider adding parts of paperwork as plugin, which seems to be not really optional in the first view. Furthermore, even the most exotic idea needs NOT to be rejected, as it can happily live as a plugin even if used only by a single person (ideally the plugin-creator/maintainer).


As for the GUI to select the plugins. I am wondering if a GUI would not contradict the plugin idea, e.g. if I want a shell only version, I need to have a graphical system purely for configuration and might need to install GTK dependencies to make it working.
How about a web-interface? That could be done in both ways.
1) Paperwork could offer a local config-webservice to download and install resp. activate and deactivate plugins. (Think of like e.g. cups is doing it).
And/Or
2) Openpaper.work, the website, could offer a configuration website where people configure their plugins and then generate a config file for paperwork including the list of files which need to be downloaded.

Thus people with a complete GUI free set-up (even no web browser) could create the config file in a nice GUI like manner online and copy the config-file to the target system. This would allow to keep the dependencies for paperwork-shell to an absolute minimum, e.g. for the operation on a RPi.

That said, I would not think too much about the GUI now. In the beginning, one can release a config-file, with a good amount of standard plugins enabled and ask the more experienced or brave users to modify the file to their needs.
 
I am very keen of the plugin system as I could easily think of many functions which are very specialized and will never make it into the core but people would love to have them if they are into it. Very exotic example... How about an MQTT-service for your smart-office which lets you add paperwork statistics in your IOT routines. Big red flashing lights, whenever the OCR hits the word invoice ;)
More realistic lists:
* Multiple document scan with physical document separators
* Send to/via...
* Contact address extraction 
* Sign / Annotate documents
* Add databases
* Web-interface
* Mobile versions
* Sync options with different backends

Just my thoughts

events.target_title: Plugins

note.body:
Hi Jerome,

thanks for your extensive reply and much more thanks for paperwork.
I agree that each and every frontend should come up with its very own way to manage the plugins. That feels much more natural rather than switching. I just had this idea to save some time.
As for how and at which point to activate the plugins, I am not sure if I would restrict the plugins to the specific platform only. Sure it makes no sens to activate GTK plugins in the Android-frontend and vice versa. However, it might make very much sense to configure the shell plugins within the GTK frontend as both might be used on the same machine. I fear that a user might get confused that he might be able to see a plugin in one, but not the other frontend. At least I would consider graying them out rather than completely remove them. E.g. On Android one can see the plugins for GTK but not activate them. On the shell one can set shell plugins and GTK plugins but not the grayed out Android plugins, etc.
Even more fine-tuned, the plugin system can have sanity checks during activation, for different plugins to come, esp. for those external plugins which rely on external features. If it fails the test, it will not be activated and the users gets an error message why it failed. Maintainers could define those checks, e.g., proof that a certain binary is available, that a certain environment is running (e.g. X, Android or Windows, etc.), in form of predefined hook-functions, which return defined error codes.
Furthermore, plugins might need their own configuration. Do you intend to let it live within paperworks config or should each and every plugin maintain its own config file?

I tried to install the working branch but could not get how it was installed in the virtualenv. make install still went fine. But I could not find paperwork-cli.

Looks great !!!

note.body:
Thanks. Though correct, that's a technician's answer, familiar with tweaking Ubuntu.

For the newbie it feels like an adventure game, where you have to know the solution upfront. Something like "*Go to the next room. Search the room. You find a switch. Flick the switch. Go back to the previous room. A door is open now.*" IMHO, that's not how a modern UI should impose knowledge on the unsuspecting user, for such a simple thing. 

Configuration should be accessible right on the object in the context menu, or somewhere as a menu entry, or in the Settings dialog of the application ITSELF. Needless to say, that I am not a big fan of this dconf Windows-registry-like backdoor approach. The success rate of hints found on the internet dealing with such technical interfaces tend to have an ever shorter period of validity. my2cents.

note.body:
> Possibly Orca could monitor plugged monitors to do that automatically

We can listen for this XkbNewKeyboardNotify event from the X server. I will look into that.

https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.7/doc/libX11/XKB/xkblib.html
"Xkb provides an XkbNewKeyboardNotify event that reports a change in keyboard geometry and/or the range of supported keycodes. The server can generate an XkbNewKeyboardNotify event when it detects a new keyboard or in response to an XkbGetKeyboardByName request that loads a new keyboard description. Selecting for XkbNewKeyboardNotify events allows Xkb-aware clients to be notified whenever a keyboard change occurs that may affect the keymap."
